column1: '''Mithe''' was a body of water in [[the Shire]]
column2: the outflow of the [[Shirebourn]] river into the [[Brandywine]].

column1: At the Mithe there was a landing-stage called [[Mithe Steps]]
column2: <ref>{{ATB|2}}</ref> from which a lane ran to [[Deephallow]] and so on to the [[Causeway]] road that went through [[Rushey]] and [[Stock]].<ref>{{ATB|Preface}}</ref>

column1: The name is obviously unrelated to the English verb ''[[Wiktionary:mithe|mithe]]'' meaning "hide
[[Andreas Möhn]] has suggested that ''Mithe'' means "Place where two streams meet"
column3: meeting of streams". Möhn adds that ''Mithe'' "is evidently related to 'mouth' and probably a derivative surviving in English place-names".<ref>{{webcite|author=[[Andreas Möhn]]|articleurl=http://lalaith.vpsurf.de/Tolkien/Bombadil_in_the_Shire.html|articlename=Bombadil in the Shire|dated=|website=Lalaith |accessed=16 May 2012}}</ref>
